large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Ming Goes to School

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Cc and Dd, engage children with a song about school, and introduce a new vocabulary word (pretends).
Begin Story Time by introducing the Big Book and asking, What does Ming do at school?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Recognize different kinds of texts/genres.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and lowercase letters in isolation.
Follow classroom rules and routines; initiate play and join a group in play.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach the letters Cc and Dd.
Read Cat Has a Cake and Dinosaurs Can .
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What games do the children play in Ming Goes to School?
How would you dress up asan astronaut?
Choose a puzzle. How do you know when you have put a piece in the right place?
Use your finger to trace the first letter of your name. Can you say the other letters in your name?
What materials would you use to make snow?
Can you find the letters C and D in the pile of Magnetic Letters?
What can you make with blocks that you think Ming would like?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Ming Goes to School

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder initiating and joining in play, and introduce a related vocabulary word (waiting).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Ming Goes to School .
Read closely and notice when Ming is initiating or joining in play.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to compare and contrast.
Initiate play and join a group in play
Follow classroom rules and routines.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to pretend to be at play in different play scenarios.
Enrich children’s social skills by modeling appropriate ways to ask to join in play.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do in school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show a picture of children learning in school?
Dress up like what you want to be one day. What will you wear? How else can you pretend?
Can you show five toy cars? How do you know there are five?
Do you have a favorite game you like to play at school? Write about it.
Can you make a picture of your classroom? What materials will you use?
Can you change the first letter in Ming’s name to make a new word?
Build a model of your school building. What materials will you use?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Ming Goes to School

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children in a song, and introduce a new vocabulary word (squirms).
Start Story Time by revisiting Ming Goes to School and asking the Guiding Question, What does Ming do at school every day?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Recognize different kinds of texts/genres.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing; write for different purposes.
Follow classroom rules and routines; initiate play and join a group in play.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children connect their own experiences to events, time, and routines.
Help children understand that school is a place where some things happen every day.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the school in Ming Goes to School like yours? How is it different?
Explain what you would need to set up a tea party.
What were the objects that Ming used to build her fairy castle? Where did it/they come from?
What are some things in Ming’s playground that are also in yours? Draw them.
What is your favorite thing to pretend to be? What would you use to make a picture of it?
What letter do the words Dad and dog have in common? What sound do they both share?
Build a fairy castle like Ming did. What materials will you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ming Goes to School by Deirdre Sullivan, illustrated by Maja Löfdahl. Text copyright © 2016 by Deirdre Sullivan. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Maja Löfdahl Green. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Sky Pony Press, a division of Skyhorse Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Our School Rules

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about school rules and introduce vocabulary words (listen, school).
Start Story Time by connecting the texts Our School Rules and Ming Goes to School.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question, What do we do at school?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to compare and contrast; recognize different kinds of texts/genres.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Separate sentence into words.
Follow rules and routines.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the rules on the Big Chart.
Ask children to match items to school rules—for example, a sponge is used when we clean up.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is your favorite part of the story about Ming?
Put together the silliest pretend costume. What does it look like? Who are you pretending to be?
Can you sort the objects at the center into objects found in nature and objects made by people?
Can you make up a rule for our classroom?
Use clay to make a sculpture of your teacher!
Can you point out a word that starts with the letter C on the Our School Rules poster? What sound does the letter C make?
What would you use to build the tallest school ever?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ming Goes to School by Deirdre Sullivan, illustrated by Maja Löfdahl. Text copyright © 2016 by Deirdre Sullivan. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Maja Löfdahl Green. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Sky Pony Press, a division of Skyhorse Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Ming Goes to School

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out and describe favorite pretend play and introduce vocabulary (giggles).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Ming Goes to School and asking, How is your school day like Ming’s?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to compare and contrast; recognize different kinds of texts/genres.
Write for different purposes.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Vote as part of a group to make decisions.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: If you could make a new game to play with your friends at school, what would the rules be?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s work.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Create a story similar to the one you’re reading.
Create a character. Dress up like that character, and tell about the character.
Use number cubes to count the letters in your name.
Can you create a story about your school day today? What details would you include?
Use crayons, markers, or colored pencils to draw a scene from your school day.
Use Magnetic Letters and place the letters in ABC order.
Build a pirate ship that you can imagine sailing away on with Ming and her friends.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Connect their life to events, time, and routines.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Connect their life to events, time, and routines.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole/small group writing activities.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Connect their life to events, time, and routines.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Separate a normally spoken four-word sentence into individual words.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole/small group writing activities.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Connect their life to events, time, and routines.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Write independently to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Engage in voting as a method for group decision-making.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
